1.content: Native Americans throughout North America lived in culturally, economically, and politically diverse ways before interactions with Europeans.

2.content: Columbus “discovered” the “New World”, ushering in the Columbian Exchange spread of goods, humans, animals & diseases in Eur., Afr., Amer.

3.content: In the Pueblo Revolt of Santa Fe, natives rebelled against the harsh encomienda system & Spanish Catholic missions’ attempts at assimilation.

4.content: The first of three Navigation Acts to impose mercantilism which regulated colonial trade (e.g. all colonial trade carried on English ships, etc.)

5.content: The first successful English settlement is at Jamestown in the Chesapeake region of Virginia. The “starving time” preceded economic success with tobacco.

6.content: The headright system is established, giving land to Virginia settlers or providing them labor through indentured servants.

7.content: The first African slaves are brought to America (at the Jamestown settlement).

8.content: The Maryland Act of Religious Toleration called for religious toleration of all Christian faiths to protect Catholics (a minority), but tensions remained.

9.content: Bacon’s Rebellion burned Jamestown over tension between white settlers wanting land & protection from natives. African slavery ↑ as a result.

10.content: Plymouth Plantation settled by “separatist” Pilgrims in Massachusetts. A poor community that endured with help of natives - (Thanksgiving).

11.content: John Winthrop’s Puritans of the Massachusetts Bay Company settled around Boston to create “a city upon a hill”.

12.content: The height of African slave trade to North America. The “middle passage” was part of the larger Triangle Trade b/t Africa, Europe, the Caribbean, Amer.

13.content: The Halfway Covenant was adopted to relax church membership requirements among second generation Puritans.

14.content: The start of the Salem Witch trials which exposed gender and economic tensions in Puritan New England society.

15.content: Jonathan Edwards delivered his “Sinners in the hands of an angry God” sermon in the midst of the Great Awakening which increased religious fervor.

16.content: Approximately 100 slaves rose up in South Carolina, seized weapons, killed several whites and attempted to flee to Florida in the Stono Rebellion.

17.content: Ben Franklin’s kite demonstration (lightning is electricity) grew out of the Enlightenment movement which  focused on logic and reason.
